componenttext: Welcome to Marsh & McLennan Companies' Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. Second quarter 2016 financial results and supplemental information were issued earlier this morning. They are available in the company's website at www.mmc.com. Please note that remarks made today may include forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements are subject to inherent risk and uncertainties and a variety of factors may cause actual results to differ materially from those contemplated by the such statements. For a more detailed discussion of these factors, please refer to our earnings release from this quarter and to our most recent SEC filings including our most recent Form 10-K. All of which are available on the MMC website. During the call today, we may also discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. For a reconciliation of these measures to the most closely comparable GAAP measures, please refer to the schedule in today's earnings release. I'll now turn this over to Dan Glaser, President and CEO of Marsh & McLennan Companies.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jamie, and good morning, and thank you for joining us to discuss our second quarter results reported earlier today. I'm Dan Glaser, President and CEO of Marsh & McLennan Companies. Joining on the call today is our CFO, Mark McGivney; Peter Zaff
componenttext:
Thank you, Jamie, and good morning, and thank you for joining us to discuss our second quarter results reported earlier today. I'm Dan Glaser, President and CEO of Marsh & McLennan Companies. Joining on the call today is our CFO, Mark McGivney; Peter Zaffino, the Chairman of Risk and Insurance Services; Julio , CEO of Mercer; Scott McDonald, CEO of Oliver Wyman; and Keith Walsh, of Investor Relations. 
Before moving onto our results, I thought I would spend a few minutes on Brexit, adding to my comments from our last earnings call. The U.K. vote to exit the EU created and meted uncertainty and volatility in capital markets throughout the world. However, over the last month, we have seen a recovery from the initial surprise of the event. Although it is too soon to predict the ultimate effects of the U.K.'s  decision, it will have implications for some of our clients. In any circumstance, Brexit will likely lead to a multiyear period of uncertainty. MMC's top priority remains supporting our clients and colleagues in the U.K. and throughout Europe. Our clients will need advise around key issues such as changes in regulatory perspectives on capital requirements, cross-border implications for employee benefit programs, work visa arrangements and the need to restructure U.K. operations in light of negotiations on passport-ing and the free movement of people. We are uniquely positioned to guide our clients through these challenges. At the same time, we are also addressing how Brexit could affect our own operations. One key question is the potential impact on the London insurance market. London is the global sector of insurance. And in our view, will likely remain so in a post-Brexit world. While underwriters will adapt over time, our geographic footprint in every EU country offers us the ability to serve clients regardless of where they are located or do business. Beyond the U.K., we have 110 offices spread throughout the remaining 27 EU member countries. Fundamentally, we operate through subsidiaries rather than branches across the EU. We capitalist tangible and we are able to place risk anywhere in the world, helping our clients avoid Brexit-related disruption around pricing terms and condition and asset-to-capacity in the market. 
In the short-term, the uncertainty in the U.K. will likely cause some clients to do projects and investments, which can impact our revenue growth in the U.K. and continental Europe. However, we believe as time passes and the political way forward becomes clearer, clients will need our help determining the best way for them to proceed strategically and structurally. Marsh and Guy Carpenter will help clients reassess their risk and insurance need as they try to protect against stress on capital and credit positions. We will also help clients monitor economic and political risks and the associated business consequences. Clients with seek Mercer's assistance with mobility and workforce planning as they consider their future organizational structures and locations. Mercer will also help with employee rewards and executive compensation design, and there may be a need for investment in asset allocation strategic advice. Oliver Wyman will play a key role hoping clients with corporate strategy, as they consider their competitive positions throughout Europe and potential need to restructure their U.K. operations. 
I also want to comment on the current state of the P&C insurance industry. The market remains stable for clients as pricing continues to decline in an orderly manner in most circumstances. Our Marsh Global REIT index continues to show mid-single-digit decreases across major products and geographies, with the steepest decline in the U.K. and the U.S. property. On the reinsurance side, we are beginning to see some moderation in rate declines, especially in U.S. pricing. Recent headlines have focused on CAT preannouncement on some of underwriters.  However, while insured natural catastrophe losses climbed over 40% in the first half of 2016, they are in line with what we have seen over the past decade. Capital remains abundant across major global markets, with surplus exceeding $1 trillion. Low interest rates are also squeezing profits for insurance carriers, as new money yields are lower than previous years. And reserve releases appear to be slowing after a decade of favorable development. Altogether, this translates into return likely below the cost of capital, net of reserve releases for a large portion of the P&C industry. We would expect this to ultimately stabilize pricing though it may take some time. To be clear, we don't anticipate industry pricing dynamics changing anytime soon. As history has shown us, some insurers will continue to write business at lower returns in declining rate environments. And in fact, we'll actually write business when rates are falling then when rates are rising. This is a topic we touched upon on our last earnings call. While there is ample capacity to place comprehensive programs at competitive prices, we believe there's an opportunity for the industry to provide greater value to clients. Success in our industry is increasingly based on delivering what matters to clients: Service; breadth of products; coverage innovation; contract certainty; claims performance; responsiveness; and yes, competitive pricing. Even in this tough market environment, underwriters continue to offer new products and services that meet a growing risk needs of our clients, and this bodes well for our industry to grow and enhance the value we deliver. 
On the health care side, we've seen recent news about proposed health insurer consolidation in the U.S. There is continued uncertainty regarding outcomes, especially in light of the recently filed DOJ lawsuits to block 2 possible mergers. Mercer will continue to be a trusted adviser regardless of the outcome of these proposed post-mergers. We will help our clients navigate all the options to design and implement benefit programs that are high quality and cost-effective for employees and their families. 
Now let me turn to our results.
MMC produced solid operating performance in the second quarter with underlying revenue growth across all 4 of our operating companies, margin expansion and 14% growth in adjusted earnings per share. MMC's revenue of $3.4 billion was the largest quarter in our history. Consolidated underwriter revenue growth was 3%, with excellent growth and profitability. Operating income rose 16% or 14% on an adjusted basis. For the 6-month period, underlying revenue growth was 4%, with margin expansion in both segments and 8% growth in adjusted earnings per share. 
Looking at Risk and Insurance Services. Second quarter revenue increased 6%, with both Marsh and Guy Carpenter contributing. Underlying revenue growth was 2%. Adjusted operating income increased double digits, with the margin expanding 120 basis points to 26.8%, our highest second quarter margin since 1988. 
I'm excited about the addition of top-flight leadership talent into RIS, reporting to Peter Zaffino. There are no finer P&C executives than John Doyle, the President of Marsh; and Peter Hearn, the President and CEO of Guy Carpenter. I am certain that John and Peter will have a positive impact on MMC. 
I'd like to give a special acknowledgment to Alex Moczarski and thank him for his leadership of Guy Carpenter over the past 5 years. We all look forward to working with Alex in his role as Chairman of MMC International. 
The Consulting segment also delivered a strong quarter with revenue increasing 4%. On an underlying basis, revenue grew 5% with both Mercer and Oliver Wyman producing solid underlying revenue growth. Adjusted operating income increased double-digit and the adjusted operating margin expanded 230 basis points to 18.7%, the segment's highest second quarter margin in over 30 years. 
In summary, we are pleased with our second quarter results. We are a trusted adviser, helping our clients addressing the issues of the day relating to risk, strategy and people. Demand for our advice and services increases in a world filled with uncertainty. We have a leadership team that ahs proven its ability to grow revenue, expand margins and improve earnings each year over multiple years. And we have the financial strength and resources to manage through periods of stress and capitalize on opportunities. 
Notwithstanding the headlines and the noise in the market, we expect to deliver another year of excellent financial performance in 2016. 
For the full year, we continue to expect underlying revenue growth within the 3% to 5% range that we have operated in for the past 6 years, meaningful margin expansion in both segments and strong EPS growth at a level approaching our long-term target of 13%. All this while continuing to invest in our future and return capital to shareholders through dividends and substantial share repurchases. With that, let me turn it over to Mark to review our second quarter results in more detail.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dan. Good morning, everyone. In the second quarter, MMC delivered strong results, driven by underlying revenue growth in each of our operating companies while continuing to actively manage expenses. Overall revenue was up 5% and underlying reve
componenttext:
Thank you, Dan. Good morning, everyone. In the second quarter, MMC delivered strong results, driven by underlying revenue growth in each of our operating companies while continuing to actively manage expenses. Overall revenue was up 5% and underlying revenue increased 3%. Adjusted operating income increased by double digits and our overall margin expanded by 190 basis points. GAAP EPS rose 17% to $0.90 and adjusted EPS increased 14% to $0.91. 
Looking at risk and insurance services, second quarter revenue was $1.8 billion, with underlying growth of 2%. Adjusted operating income increased 11% to $493 million with a margin expanding 140 basis points to 26.8%. 
At Marsh, revenue in the quarter was $1.6 billion, an increase of 6%. The top line was bolstered by quality acquisition such as in the U.K. and continued activity with Marsh & McLennan agency. On an underlying basis, revenue rose 2%; underlying growth was 4% in the international division; EMEA increased a solid 3% with growth across all regions; Asia Pacific was up 2% in Latin America had a strong growth of 11%; and the U.S./Canada division, underlying revenue was flat. We continue to see pressure in Canada and in parts of the U.S., largely driven by commodity-related headwinds. Guy Carpenter's revenue was $285 million, an increase of 3% on both a recorded and underlying basis. Another good performance. Growth was highlighted by strong new business across Asia Pacific, EMEA and Global Specialties. Guy Carpenter has produced positive underlying revenue growth and 28 in the past 30 quarters. 
In the Consulting segment, revenue rose 4% to $1.5 billion or 5% on an underlying basis. Adjusted operating income increased 18% to $288 million and the adjusted operating margin expanded 230 basis points to 18.7%. 
Mercer's revenue increased 3% to $1.1 billion, reflecting underlying growth of 4%. Solid growth in the quarter reflects the benefits of the diversified portfolio. Investments and talent both rose 6%, health increased 5% and retirement was up 2%. 
All major geographic regions contributed led by growth market. Oliver Wyman continued to perform well. Revenue was $460 million, reflecting solid growth of 5% on both the reported and underlying basis. Growth was well distributed with particular strength in Europe and other international markets. 
In the third quarter, we expect to see a decline in underlying revenue from Oliver Wyman. This is driven by comparisons of very strong growth in the financial services practice last year as well as global growth concerns exacerbated by Brexit uncertainty. 
As Dan said, we continue to expect that for 2016, we will generate underlying revenue growth in the 3% to 5% range, increased operating margins in both segments and strong growth in earnings per share.
Let's make a few comments about our global retirement plan. We normally discuss the outlook for retirement plan expense after we have completed the annual year-end measurement process. However, given the decline in the interest rate, we want to share some thought that might be helpful to investors. We monitor our retirement program on an ongoing basis. Previously, we discussed several changes that reduced the sensitivity of our retirement expense to interest rates. As we have said many times, we view retirement expenses as just 1 component of overall expense, which we actively manage. We have been effectively mitigating retirement plan volatility and limiting the impact to shareholders over the past couple of years. Based on where we stand today, we expect to do so in 2017. 
Moving to Investment income. We recognized $1 million in the second quarter, a decrease from $3 million a year ago. For 2016, we expect to generate only modest investment income compared with $38 million we reported in 2015. 
On our last earnings call, we estimated the impact from foreign exchange would be de minimis for the remainder of 2016. As expected, the effect of foreign exchange in adjusted EPS was negligible in the second quarter, and our outlook for the rest of the year has not changed. There has been recent volatility in the British pound. The weakening of the pound has a minimal overall impact to MMC. This is because RIS have a natural hedge crated by U.S. dollar placements in London. While the weakening -- while the impact of the weakening pound to MMC in total was not significant, there would be a benefit to RIS offset by an adverse impact to consulting. 
Our tax rate fluctuates from quarter-to-quarter, reflecting the geographic mix of earnings, tax elements, completion of open tax years and other items. Our adjusted tax rate in the second quarter was 29.1% compared to 27.4% in the same quarter last year. Through the first half of the year, our adjusted tax rate was 28.8% compared with 28.5% in last year's first half. 
Based on the current landscape, it is reasonable to assume a tax rate of 29% for the remainder of 2016.
Corporate debt at June 30 was $4.8 billion, which declined from $5 billion at the end of the first quarter with the reduction in commercial paper outstanding. The term structure of our debt portfolio provides us flexibility with modest near-term repayment obligations. Our net debt maturity is $250 million of senior notes due next April. 
In the second quarter, we repurchased 3.5 million shares of our stock for $225 million. For 6 months, we used $425 million to buy back 7 million shares. The second quarter marks the 17th consecutive quarter we have bought back our stock, and we have reduced shares outstanding 9 quarters in a row. Since announcing our commitment to reduce our annual share count at Investor Day, in March 2014, shares outstanding have declined by 30 million or 5%. Our cash position at the end of the second quarter was $974 million, with approximately $170 million in the U.S. Uses of cash in the second quarter included $225 million for share repurchases, $165 million for dividends and $47 million for acquisitions. 
For the first 6 months, uses of cash included $425 million for share repurchases, $326 million for dividends and $168 million for acquisitions. 
For the full year 2016, we continue to expect to deploy roughly $2.3 billion of capital through dividends, share repurchases, acquisitions and investments. We also expect to deliver on our annual capital return commitments to reduce our share count and increase our dividend per share by double digits. 
And with that, I'm happy to turn it back over to Dan.

componenttextpreview: Before I hand over to Peter, I would just say that in general, when you look at the size of Marsh, it's in every country which has insurance profile, many different segments, many different moving parts within the business. So it really gets a very broad
componenttext: Before I hand over to Peter, I would just say that in general, when you look at the size of Marsh, it's in every country which has insurance profile, many different segments, many different moving parts within the business. So it really gets a very broad array of areas in which it can grow. Wherever there is growth, we're on the ground to capture it. I think the reality as  you've seen from a lot of the insurance company reporting, it's a pretty tough market out there. There is -- the P&C rating levels are under a fair amount of pressure. There's a significant amount of competition amongst brokers, et cetera, which is having an impact. But I do think you have to look at it on a mixed basis. International did quite well. U.S./Canada was under a bit more pressure. But Peter, you want to give us more color on this?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Dan. Just to pick up on what you just said. International, I think, we had a terrific quarter. Strong organic growth in all major geographies. Some of the highlights were Latin America. We had 11% underlying organic growth and also over 15% new busi
componenttext: Sure, Dan. Just to pick up on what you just said. International, I think, we had a terrific quarter. Strong organic growth in all major geographies. Some of the highlights were Latin America. We had 11% underlying organic growth and also over 15% new business growth. We had some real strong performances in Asia, and in EMEA having 3% growth in the second quarter, was terrific. And it was led by strong new business in Continental Europe. If you go and shift into the U.S. and Canada. Again, each quarter is really quite different. Overall, we're not pleased with a 0% growth in the quarter. But it is just 1 quarter. The fundamentals of the business are sound. What are still some of the fundamentals look out a certainly the renewal book. And we look at client retention, it was at historic highs. We've done really well. Strong new business. The challenges we had are really tough comparable year-on-year in the business in U.S./Canada division. It was a record in second quarter 2015. We had a lot more nonrecurring new business that we have had historically. We matched that new business in  this particular quarter, but it was hard to grow year-over-year. And that nonrecurring business that have an impact of not having renewal line grow as much as we have seen in the past. The division continues to be challenged by Canada, which is particularly exposed to commodity prices. We talked about this in the past. Project work which does a little bit of a new business. And despite the cash that we saw in Canada in the quarter, insurance pricing is still a headwind. And then just one last comment on another variable, Dan mentioned it in his opening comments is that while the rate decreases are orderly, they sequentially have increased a little bit on the property side in the U.S. And that had a little bit of an impact as well. But again, I look at client retention, new business and the underlying performance of the fundamentals. And I think U.S. and Canada will do well as it has historically when we look at the full year.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what we said about margins in the past is you really shouldn't look at any individual quarter that certainly on a year-to-date basis, when we get further along in the year, we're on a rolling 4-quarter basis is the best way to look at margins. The r
componenttext: Well, what we said about margins in the past is you really shouldn't look at any individual quarter that certainly on a year-to-date basis, when we get further along in the year, we're on a rolling 4-quarter basis is the best way to look at margins. The reality is, both RIS and consulting, we have had significant efficiency gains over multiple periods of time. And so when we look at the expansion of the margins, it's been pretty consistent over multiple years. I was just looking the other day in the second quarter over a 5-year period, the margin for RIS is up almost 500 basis points. And for consulting, about 600 basis points. And so there has been a consistent level of significant margin expansion. We expect 2015 to be a good year for margin expansion despite the slow growth environment within RIS.

componenttext: A couple of things, and then I'll hand off to Peter, Larry. I mean the one thing you have to know is that organizations like Marsh and others are always searching for ways of delivering increased value to clients. And that value is both in the advisory side, which probably has had even more increased value to clients over the last several years than any other area. But it also touches a transactional side as well. And clearly, whether it's quota shares or specific types of facilities, there has been some level of increase in that over the last few years. And whether that is a permanent feature of the landscape or a factor of the current market conditions, time will tell. But Peter, do you have something to add to that?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think just to add to what you said, strategy to what any facilities, or quota shares is always believe the client valuable together dedicated for us capacity where we think there's a need in a market. I mean, the most recent example for us is we la
componenttext: Yes. I think just to add to what you said, strategy to what any facilities, or quota shares is always believe the client valuable together dedicated for us capacity where we think there's a need in a market. I mean, the most recent example for us is we launched facility, which is led by 5 every strong lead markets. We're able to put together $250 million of capacity for anywhere in the world from those leads. And then we have another $250 million  of following capacity. So we'll be able to have $500 million of capacity for value for clients anywhere in the world, really does generate value. And to do that on a syndicated individual basis will be near on impossible for all of our clients across the world. The world always focus on client value and bringing capacity to the market where there was need.

componenttextpreview: But you got it right identified and acquisitions through the first half of the year are not at a pace of what they were last year. I'll just remind everybody that we don't have any budget with regard to acquisitions. We look at a lot of things. We cultiva
componenttext: But you got it right identified and acquisitions through the first half of the year are not at a pace of what they were last year. I'll just remind everybody that we don't have any budget with regard to acquisitions. We look at a lot of things. We cultivate a lot of relationships, and we have a lot of conversations. We don't do very much at all even over the past years. We've had a string of pearls strategy, and we are continuing on that basis. So acquisitions by their very nature are going to be lumpy. In some years, we're going to have lots of them, and some years, won't have that much. I can tell you the back half of last year was more active than the first half of last year. I don't know whether that's going to be the case this year or not. Our pipelines are actually pretty good. But we're a disciplined acquirer. And so what I can say is that if acquisitions are lighter-than-normal than any given year, we're not seeking to build cash on our balance sheet. So we would use that -- those funds in other ways of creating value whether that's organic investments or strategic recruitment. Whether that is increased share repurchases. Whether that is essentially avenues that we would take to make sure that we're putting our cash to work.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So before I hand over to Julio, I just want to remind you that the margins are for segment and not for individual operating companies. So the Consulting segment's margins have expanded pretty dramatically, as I mentioned before, about 700 bps over t
componenttext: Okay. So before I hand over to Julio, I just want to remind you that the margins are for segment and not for individual operating companies. So the Consulting segment's margins have expanded pretty dramatically, as I mentioned before, about 700 bps over the last 5 years. And there's a lot of factors to do with that. As we've said in other calls in the past,  the better the top line performance, the better the opportunities for margin expansion certainly over time over any kind of stretch of time. But both Julio and Scott have done a number of things over the years to make sure that we're positioned well to expand margins into the future. Julioi, do you want to comment in more detail?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thank you, and thanks for the question. As we talked about in the past, I mean, Marsh is a pretty  broad business and gives us a lot of different opportunities to align margin expansion and ensure that our top line and our expense growth has a lot o
componenttext: Sure. Thank you, and thanks for the question. As we talked about in the past, I mean, Marsh is a pretty  broad business and gives us a lot of different opportunities to align margin expansion and ensure that our top line and our expense growth has a lot of air between them over sustainable periods of time. And so you see things that we make conscious decisions like disinvesting and things that don't give us the margin expansion or sustainability across the contribution into the future. One of the more primary recent examples of that is when we decided to disinvest in our DC record keeping business and strike up a strategic relationship with a partner that we can continue to have as part of a bundled solution into the future. And we continue to make active decisions like that. Our continued efficiency in our consultancy and administration businesses is really bolstered around a disciplined around higher utilization and use of off shoring is another example of what we do to continue to drive efficiency and air between expenses and revenue. Also the evolving mix of our business. I mean, there's no question that as you look at the improvements in operating leverage, you see businesses that have that operating leverage being more significant part of our mix, and that's going to have a sustainable impact over the long run. And our continuous portfolio review is also a part of our discipline now, and we accelerate those things to give us margin accretiveness and decelerate those things that don't. So it's really a lot about being very disciplined around ensuring that we are building the business that can have strength, both in the top line and on the bottom line, as we continue to grow. And I just also want to mention that importantly, our overall focus is still to increase and grow earnings. And we're confident that with the actions that we've taken and the actions that we continue to take, that we'll be successful in doing just that.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent, Julio. I just want to caution everybody not to overly focus on 1 quarter when it comes to margin. That at the end of the day, look over longer searches of time. The Consulting segment is up about 60 bps on a year-to-date basis. We expect that t
componenttext: Excellent, Julio. I just want to caution everybody not to overly focus on 1 quarter when it comes to margin. That at the end of the day, look over longer searches of time. The Consulting segment is up about 60 bps on a year-to-date basis. We expect that to improve over the course of the year, but we certainly don't look at 230 bps margin expansion in the quarter as being some sort of new run rate for the Consulting division. Next question, please.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. One other quick question. Peter, just you mentioned the historically high retention that you had in the quarter but also talked about nonrecurring business. I know those are 2 separate things. But can you kind of help us understand maybe how m
componenttext: Understood. One other quick question. Peter, just you mentioned the historically high retention that you had in the quarter but also talked about nonrecurring business. I know those are 2 separate things. But can you kind of help us understand maybe how much of the book is business that you guys view sort of nonrecurring? And/or what is the typical type of nonrecurring business versus the rest of the book?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I'll just take that a little bit and then hand over to Peter. I mean, one thing to bear in mind when we talk about client retention is retaining the client. It doesn't necessarily mean that the income for that client is exactly what it was the ye
componenttext: Okay. So I'll just take that a little bit and then hand over to Peter. I mean, one thing to bear in mind when we talk about client retention is retaining the client. It doesn't necessarily mean that the income for that client is exactly what it was the year before. So for Peter, I don't think you want to go into detail about recurring revenues and that sort of things.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. But let's give one example. Construction surety that could be some project work that could be some work within the private equity space that we have, a very good business for the United States. So even if there's more activity on the business in 1 par
componenttext: No. But let's give one example. Construction surety that could be some project work that could be some work within the private equity space that we have, a very good business for the United States. So even if there's more activity on the business in 1 particular quarter, that is a nonrecurring piece of business. So we want to be very active in that construction business and private equity and make sure that we're capturing all the new business opportunities. But that's not a same as winning a property deal that will go into client retention and net renewal retention the following year. So that was a little bit more color on my comments from earlier.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Michael Nannizzi with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Michael Nannizzi with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I just wanted to talk a little bit more about U.S. and Canada, obviously, the organic was flat. But when I look back further, revenue in that geography is up like 30% in the last 4 years, which is I think better than any other subset in your business o
componenttext: So I just wanted to talk a little bit more about U.S. and Canada, obviously, the organic was flat. But when I look back further, revenue in that geography is up like 30% in the last 4 years, which is I think better than any other subset in your business over that period. And I'm guessing, obviously, MMC Agency is a big chunk of that. So on this front to think about margins, normally when we think about margins relative to organic growth, but here, given the trajectory of margins in the segment, I'm guessing margins have expanded in the U.S. and Canada as well over that period. How should we think about the trajectory for the U.S./Canada business? How much more important are acquisitions here relative to organic when we think about top line? When we think about bottom line?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's a couple of things. Well, yes, you're right when you're looking at the overall revenue growth in U.S. and Canada that is inclusive of acquisitions. And in fact, Marsh had a strong quarter on overall growth. And that really varies based upon
componenttext: Well, there's a couple of things. Well, yes, you're right when you're looking at the overall revenue growth in U.S. and Canada that is inclusive of acquisitions. And in fact, Marsh had a strong quarter on overall growth. And that really varies based upon the acquisitions, which were done in the prior year. And clearly, one of the core strategic initiatives of the company since 2009 has been the development of the Marsh & McLennan agency. And you can see through the contingent payments that we've made over the last several years that agency -- many parts of agency are performing better than what our expectations were when we acquired different agencies. So yes, there is -- when you have an active acquisition strategy, then clearly, the combination of active acquisition performance and efficiencies gained through acquisitions, combined with organic would have an impact on margins. I think it's important. We talk about margins and we all recognize around the stable that margins are in important feature. Margin expansion is an important feature of us delivering on our long-term CAGR of EPS of 13%. Having said that, I do want to reiterate to everybody that margins are about the last thing we talk about at an executive team level. We spent a lot of time on financial performance, organic growth strategies, acquisition strategies, people issues, risk issues. We believe that margin expansion is an outcome of running our business properly, not a goal in it of itself. So I just want to level set by that. Peter, I don't know if you have anything else to add to that.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I would add is that the acquisition strategy is important to us, but that is not in lieu of growing each of our businesses organically. We focus on what investments we need to make in each of the components of our U.S. and Canada business i
componenttext: The only thing I would add is that the acquisition strategy is important to us, but that is not in lieu of growing each of our businesses organically. We focus on what investments we need to make in each of the components of our U.S. and Canada business in terms of how they can grow irrespective of acquisitions. But we have an active acquisition strategy where we have a very strong pipeline and believe that will supplement the organic growth in the U.S. and Canada division.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. I mean I guess and thinking about that, the U.S. and Canada then, is an acquisition growth, maybe not a driver but is it an ingredient to margin expansion if you don't have consistent organic growth? Does it help to tailwind to margin expansion?
componenttext: Got it. I mean I guess and thinking about that, the U.S. and Canada then, is an acquisition growth, maybe not a driver but is it an ingredient to margin expansion if you don't have consistent organic growth? Does it help to tailwind to margin expansion?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, acquisitions done well and quality acquisitions that have higher growth than what your expectations were will create more value. But overall, I got to tell you, marsh & McLennan agency has been a headwind for margin expansion for this seg
componenttext: Well, certainly, acquisitions done well and quality acquisitions that have higher growth than what your expectations were will create more value. But overall, I got to tell you, marsh & McLennan agency has been a headwind for margin expansion for this segment. When you look at the amortization that we have added over a number of years, the net operating income margins of MMA now are lower than the margins for  greater -- than greater segment. So from that perspective, overtime, that will be, more of a tailwind as the amortization schedule falls off. But fundamentally, MMA has not been a help to Peter and his team on margins. And Peter and his team has proven -- because even if you look over the last number of years, we're getting about the 2% growth within Marsh in the last couple of quarters. Marsh over a number of years has averaged about 3%, which is really at the lower end of organic or underlying growth where we would expect to have any reasonable amount of margin expansion. But we -- knowing where we're going to be looking out into the future where we're likely to be and planning for it allows us to manage our expenses very carefully to where in virtually every corner, over revenue growth exceeds our expense growth. And when it doesn't, it's purposeful. We know it, we plan for it and we decide to do it. And so we're not holding up to the fact that we always have to happen that way. In fact Peter and I talk all the time that for the right opportunities, organic or  recruitment wise, we will always go into the tank expense wise to build a better business. And so that is part of what we are willing to do. But we're seeking for those opportunities. They don't unveil themselves all that often. So the net effect of running the business on a consistent basis where revenue growth exceeds expense growth means we'll always have margin expansion.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, great. And if I could sneak in a quick on just on the Consulting segment. I think, Mark, you mentioned about Oliver Wyman impact from Brexit in the U.K. Any impact on Mercer that we should think about? Or offsetting impact is to sort of keep in li
componenttext: Got it, great. And if I could sneak in a quick on just on the Consulting segment. I think, Mark, you mentioned about Oliver Wyman impact from Brexit in the U.K. Any impact on Mercer that we should think about? Or offsetting impact is to sort of keep in line with your outlook for mid-single-digit organic growth and margin expansion?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So let me hand off to Scott little bit just to give you a little bit more flavor on Oliver Wyman, which obviously, over the last several years, has been our fastest-growing operating company. But we've said many times in the past, it will be our mos
componenttext: Okay. So let me hand off to Scott little bit just to give you a little bit more flavor on Oliver Wyman, which obviously, over the last several years, has been our fastest-growing operating company. But we've said many times in the past, it will be our most volatile operating company as well because of the nature of its business. And then after Scott, we'll hand over to Julio and talk a little bit about Brexit and what he is seeing right now with Mercer. So Scott?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me give you  some context before I go straight to the third quarter. Oliver Wyman is a strong business, and we're very confident that over time, we can grow it at mid- to high single digits as we've indicated consistently. However, quarter-to-qu
componenttext: Sure. Let me give you  some context before I go straight to the third quarter. Oliver Wyman is a strong business, and we're very confident that over time, we can grow it at mid- to high single digits as we've indicated consistently. However, quarter-to-quarter, there'll be a fair bit of volatility and the reasons for that is that the majority of our revenues are nonrecurring, and we need to generate them as new business every year. So in any one quarter, we can have very strong growth like you've seen in the first quarter of this year or through 2014. But we can also have some downside volatility. In addition to that, we had a few very strong years in Oliver Wyman, setting up some pretty tough comparables for us. But in the third quarter, we will see a decline and that comes primarily from our Financial Services business, which has grown even faster than Oliver Wyman overall. And beyond Financial Services, we're feeling only a modest slowdown at this point across the portfolio, driven by the slower economic growth expectation, exacerbated a little bit by Brexit. So we still see very little to suggest this is any structural weakness and the business still feels very sound. So we're expecting to dip to be short-term. Although it may take 1 quarter or 2 to work out.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. Julio, do you want to talk about Brexit and what you're seeing at Mercer?
componenttext: Thanks, Scott. Julio, do you want to talk about Brexit and what you're seeing at Mercer?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. I think there's a lot of continued uncertainty, of course, around Brexit and the short as well as long-term implications of such. In the early days, as you can imagine, there's a significant amount of discussions that are taking place with our
componenttext: Yes, sure. I think there's a lot of continued uncertainty, of course, around Brexit and the short as well as long-term implications of such. In the early days, as you can imagine, there's a significant amount of discussions that are taking place with our primary client around things like workforce planning, what's going to happen if migrant issues are resolved one way or the other, what potentially could happen in terms of the investment strategy going forward for pensions. And all of that we are actively involve in. Throughout those discussions you can imagine a bit of a slowdown in terms of that discretionary spend until the path is clear. And we  totally have an opportunity to propose some strategy on how to go forward. But let me clarify that increased uncertainty and market volatility will likely create some opportunities for us. And as clients are going to look for advice, of course, to manage in that uncertain world and through the issues. So in the longer-term, we'll look to develop these solutions to continue to meet these emerging needs. And as I said examples would be the potential changes in the flow of capital investments as well as in regulations with regard to workforce, benefits and pension coverage.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Kai Pan with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Kai Pan with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Just one follow-up with Mark on the pension expenses. Given if interest rate stays at current levels, what's the magnitude of the potential impact relative to 2015, to $125 million? And would you be able to fully offset that like you did in 2015?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, do you want to take that?
componenttext: Mark, do you want to take that?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kai. Just a couple of things. First, on the sensitivity. As we said in our 10-K, roughly 50 basis points of discount rate change will have a $35 million or so impact on earnings. The comments -- the recently included -- the comments on pensions becau
componenttext: Yes, Kai. Just a couple of things. First, on the sensitivity. As we said in our 10-K, roughly 50 basis points of discount rate change will have a $35 million or so impact on earnings. The comments -- the recently included -- the comments on pensions because it is so ask a lot of questions from investors and try to pick up a newspaper without reading something about it given little interest rate environment. So we just wanted to share where -- how we're  thinking about it right now and one to highlight what I just talked about that we are less sensitive today to interest rate volatility than we were. And if you go back a couple of years ago, we closed our largest benefit plan in the U.K. We closed our Irish plant. We need the changes that we talked about to our U.S. plans. sensitivity so that's a factoring and you remember what really matters is the interest rate environment at the end of the year. So although we've seen a drop in rates here in the first half of the year, just in the U.S. in the last couple of weeks, rates have come back a little bit, and asset value have actually come back off their post-Brexit lows. And so how we're looking at this, we're at the very beginning of our planning process. And as I said a few minutes ago, pension expense is just one element of an overall expense rate base that we manage very actively and we manage to deliver great results. And so given where we are in the year, we could see this coming. We could plan under a number of scenarios. And based on where we see things today, we expect we'll be able to limit the impact of pension volatility on earnings just we have for the last couple of years.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Anything else, Kai?
componenttext: Anything else, Kai?

componenttextpreview: As we said, Kai, in past calls, it's looking for solutions for long-term health rent reduction and our exchange is certainly one of those that we discussed actively. We're really focused on that and continue to be extending the platform beyond experience.
componenttext: As we said, Kai, in past calls, it's looking for solutions for long-term health rent reduction and our exchange is certainly one of those that we discussed actively. We're really focused on that and continue to be extending the platform beyond experience. So it's a full year of platform for employees to consult with. As mentioned in recent past, we would -- we see a lot of interest and a lot of discussions. But I would say that we're experiencing a softer conversion the sales than what we had originally anticipated for the selling season. We'll see how it comes out completely at the end. But certainly, a little bit slower than we expected.

componenttext: Okay. So we're not going to break out MMA in any kind of formal way. We have said in the past that our expectations was that it would grow faster than overall Marsh. We were comfortable that it was exceeding our expectations on that score. And it did so again in the second quarter.

componenttext: Okay, great. And then just in terms of the margins that you saw in both of the segments. I know pension was a benefit with a hit last year and a little bit of a benefit this year. Is there a way that we should be thinking about the impact that pension had on the Q2 margins just in terms of how we think of the level of margin improvement for the balance of the year in both of the segments? Or would you to say kind of it didn't have as much of an impact that we shouldn't be really backing that out?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would look at it this way, one, just to reiterate. Look over longer periods. So year-to-date, in rolling 4 quarters are more accurate ways and margin expansion. And even though we don't unpack pension, it's fair to say pension was a benefit. But we woul
componenttext: I would look at it this way, one, just to reiterate. Look over longer periods. So year-to-date, in rolling 4 quarters are more accurate ways and margin expansion. And even though we don't unpack pension, it's fair to say pension was a benefit. But we would've have had significant margin expansion in both segments even without contemplating the pension credit that we had. And so I would just look over longer periods as to where the likely run rate of the expansion is.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: I'll hand off to Mark in a second. But projects can be lumpy as well. And so from that standpoint, I mean, our capital expenditure over the last several years has been bounded in kind of a $300 million to $400 million annual kind of spend. We're probably still in that area. Some projects are complicated, and we always prioritize. The best projects are the ones that are done well. And so that creates a little bit of a gating mechanism, which has an impact. But Mark, do you have anything else that?

componenttext: Yes. The only thing I would add is someone who reads too much into the slow start. It's more just timing of starting something projects mainly on the technology side. So we had $325 million of CapEx last year, probably a little bit less than that but we still expect in the high $200 million to $300 million range.

componenttext: Kind of continuing the conversation of M&A and so forth. You guys obviously have a conservative balance sheet with debt-to-EBITDA I think maybe it's around 1.6 right now. And my sense is you'd like to maintain that just to be able to seize an opportunity as they arise. Can you give us maybe a little bit more color on if you're seeing increased opportunities, especially in light of the volatility in Brexit that might be servicing now that wouldn't have been there, say, 3 or 6 months ago? Or is it still going to be the string of pearls strategy that you've been executing in the past?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know if you would or not. But ultimately, what you're saying could very well happen. There could be opportunities in parts of the world based upon uncertainty. Whether it's caused by Brexit or other factors. Clearly, macro factors have a role to p
componenttext: I don't know if you would or not. But ultimately, what you're saying could very well happen. There could be opportunities in parts of the world based upon uncertainty. Whether it's caused by Brexit or other factors. Clearly, macro factors have a role to play in M&A and in continuing M&A. It's too early in looking at Brexit to see whether there's truly any new opportunity that are going to result from Brexit. But suffice to say that your basic premise of we're relatively comfortable at our level of leverage now and that our level of leverage preserves the capability for us to capitalize on opportunities if they may appear sometime in the future is accurate. We think we live in a pretty and certain volatile world and in uncertain volatile world, difficult conditions, there may be the best opportunities that you'll ever see. We certainly want to serve the ability to capitalize if they so appear.

componenttext: So I'll stay tune on that. Just coming back to U.S./Canada. I want to look forward a little bit more to kind of what happened. componenttext: Yes. Again, we could -- if we spoke about  the U.S./Canada division going into each of its component would take a lot of time. We don't break them out. There's a lot of businesses. componenttextpreview: Yes. I wouldn't think so. I mean, at the end, I don't think we don't have that level of granularity to know what's in the client's minds. I do believe that it's fair to say Brexit or otherwise, that many of our clients believe that we are living in an age
componenttext: Yes. I wouldn't think so. I mean, at the end, I don't think we don't have that level of granularity to know what's in the client's minds. I do believe that it's fair to say Brexit or otherwise, that many of our clients believe that we are living in an age of risk and uncertainty. And that risk and uncertainty creates a dampening enthusiasm for projects and for investments. So that has had an impact over the last number of years I think on not only our growth levels but on GDP worldwide. But there was no negative or positive spike that we could actually see as a result of early-stage thought about Brexit.

componenttext: Dan, you made an interesting comment in your prepared remarks that RIS margins are at highest it's been since 1988, hard market year and a high interest rates shows that operational efficiency gains made over that period of time. I'm curious looking forward another and not a quarter, not a year. What are the biggest levers for you guys to achieve opportunity or efficiency gains in your business on par with that aside of just the pricing environment?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Charles, I would say that it's always funny comparing ourselves back into time. We're such a different company than where we were back in 1988 that I'm loath to create those comparisons even though we're right them into our script. I would say we're bette
componenttext: Charles, I would say that it's always funny comparing ourselves back into time. We're such a different company than where we were back in 1988 that I'm loath to create those comparisons even though we're right them into our script. I would say we're better than in at anytime of our history. Because when I look back at 1988, if you look at total RIS, it was $1.3 billion of revenue. I mean, we are multiple times larger and more diverse geographically, line of business, quality, et cetera. And so this is the new world. I don't set margin targets. Peter doesn't as well. We don't believe in them. We believe that there something about the human brain that looks at a target as something to reach and then draw back from. So I would not put out any hurdle out there and that's what this business could do and how it can perform. I do know that I'm quite confident that the leading factor in how we will do over time is organic growth. And if we have good levels of organic growth, we will have good levels of margin expansion period. If we don't have that organic growth, then all of our annual and multiyear search for efficiency, obviously, that never ends. We have different ways of running this business through structure, through the layering, through technology, through better levels of client connectivity to create more ability for us to service clients on an efficient basis. And that creates a margin benefits was going forward. But you have any other questions, Charles? I think we have time for one more question.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean it's a question that I'm used to because when I joined in the business in 1982, I was reading articles about brokerage disintermediation that was written in 1978. And considering should I actually join an industry that looks like it's going t
componenttext: Well, I mean it's a question that I'm used to because when I joined in the business in 1982, I was reading articles about brokerage disintermediation that was written in 1978. And considering should I actually join an industry that looks like it's going to the . The reality is that an increasingly complex world, the need for advice rises. And these were once transactional businesses. Now they are principally advisory businesses with transactional capability. Big, big difference. So I would say overall level risk of disintermediation is quite low. That's not saying that does not ways of creating distribution that we as a company have to be very focused on whether it's digital, whether it's online, whether it's worksite. There's different ways of getting to our client base, and we had to be very open to the idea. And clearly, as some parts of the segments, I feel that you'll have multi channels, right? Whether you look at motor or homeowners or maybe even small commercial. You'll end up having multi channels which means brokers, remain direct affinity there will be many different avenues for clients to be satisfied. The key is, what's the client experience, who provides the best level of comprehensive client experienced in a little bit less about was the capital line it. It's more about experience. Announces and with the thought as well because I recently took a trip into a country which was always very much on our broker market, which is beginning to turn more and more into a broker market. The reality is that more parts of the world have become brokers because the terms and conditions enterprising are better and markets in which brokers are active than in where brokers are not active. And so I feel pretty comfortable that we're positioned well. But not securing our position in the market. We have to always find ways of doing things better or else, yes, we would get this intermediated reps with other intermediaries but the always have the table in our toasted do things better. I think that's it, operator, where we can end the call because I know we're beyond 1 hour. I just want to thank everybody for joining us this morning. Specifically, thank our clients for their support including us and our colleagues for their hard work and dedication in serving our clients. Thank you very much.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Marsh & McLennan Companies' Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. Second quarter 2016 financial results and supplemental information were issued earlier this morning. They are available in the company's website at www.mmc.com. Please
componenttext:
Welcome to Marsh & McLennan Companies' Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. Second quarter 2016 financial results and supplemental information were issued earlier this morning. They are available in the company's website at www.mmc.com. Please note that remarks made today may include forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, and a variety of factors may cause actual results to differ materially from those contemplated by such statements. For a more detailed discussion of those factors, please refer to our earnings release from this quarter and to our most recent SEC filings, including our most recent Form 10-K, all of which are available on the MMC website. During the call today, we may also discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. For a reconciliation of these measures to the most closely comparable GAAP measures, please refer to the schedule in today's earnings release.
I'll now turn this over to Dan Glaser, President and CEO of Marsh & McLennan Companies.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jamie, and good morning, and thank you for joining us to discuss our second quarter results reported earlier today. I'm Dan Glaser, President and CEO of Marsh & McLennan Companies. Joining me on the call today is our CFO, Mark McGivney; Peter Z
componenttext:
Thank you, Jamie, and good morning, and thank you for joining us to discuss our second quarter results reported earlier today. I'm Dan Glaser, President and CEO of Marsh & McLennan Companies. Joining me on the call today is our CFO, Mark McGivney; Peter Zaffino, the Chairman of Risk and Insurance Services; Julio Portalatin, CEO of Mercer; Scott McDonald, CEO of Oliver Wyman; and Keith Walsh of Investor Relations.
Before moving onto our results, I thought I would spend a few minutes on Brexit, adding to my comments from our last earnings call. The U.K. vote to exit the EU created immediate uncertainty and volatility in capital markets throughout the world. However, over the last month, we have seen a recovery from the initial surprise of the event. Although it is too soon to predict the ultimate effects of the U.K.'s decision, it will have implications for some of our clients. In any circumstance, Brexit will likely lead to a multiyear period of uncertainty. MMC's top priority remains supporting our clients and colleagues in the U.K. and throughout Europe. Our clients will need advise around key issues, such as changes in regulatory perspectives on capital requirements, cross-border implications for employee benefit programs, work visa arrangements and the need to restructure U.K. operations in light of negotiations on passporting and the free movement of people. We are uniquely positioned to guide our clients through these challenges. At the same time, we are also addressing how Brexit could affect our own operations. One key question is the potential impact on the London insurance market. London is the global center of insurance and, in our view, will likely remain so in a post-Brexit world. While underwriters will adapt over time, our geographic footprint in every EU country offers us the ability to serve clients regardless of where they are located or do business. Beyond the U.K., we have 110 offices spread throughout the remaining 27 EU member countries. Fundamentally, we operate through subsidiaries rather than branches across the EU. We view capital as fungible, and we are able to place risk anywhere in the world, helping our clients avoid Brexit-related disruption around pricing terms and conditions and assets to capacity in the market.
In the short-term, the uncertainty in the U.K. will likely cause some clients to defer projects and investments, which can impact our revenue growth in the U.K. and Continental Europe. However, we believe as time passes and the political way forward becomes clearer, clients will need our help determining the best way for them to proceed strategically and structurally. Marsh and Guy Carpenter will help clients reassess their risk and insurance needs as they try to protect against stress on capital and credit positions. We will also help clients monitor economic and political risks and the associated business consequences. Clients will seek Mercer's assistance with mobility and workforce planning as they consider their future organizational structures and locations. Mercer will also help with employee rewards and executive compensation design, and there may be a need for investment in asset allocation strategic advice. Oliver Wyman will play a key role helping clients with corporate strategy as they consider their competitive positioning throughout Europe and potential need to restructure their U.K. operations.
I also want to comment on the current state of the P&C insurance industry. The market remains favorable for clients as pricing continues to decline in an orderly manner in most circumstances. Our Marsh Global REIT Index continues to show mid-single-digit decreases across major products and geographies with the steepest declines in the U.K. and U.S. property. On the reinsurance side, we are beginning to see some moderation in rate declines, especially in U.S. pricing. Recent headlines have focused on CAT preannouncement among underwriters. However, while insured natural catastrophe losses climbed over 40% in the first half of 2016, they are in line with what we have seen over the past decade. Capital remains abundant across major global markets with surplus exceeding $1 trillion. Low interest rates are also squeezing profits for insurance carriers as new money yields are lower than previous years. And reserve releases appear to be slowing after a decade of favorable development. Altogether, this translates into returns likely below the cost of capital, net of reserve releases, for a large portion of the P&C industry. We would expect this to ultimately stabilize pricing, though it may take some time. To be clear, we don't anticipate industry pricing dynamics changing anytime soon. As history has shown us, some insurers will continue to write business at lower returns in declining rate environments. And in fact, we'll actually write more new business when rates are falling than when rates are rising. This is a topic we touched upon on our last earnings call. While there is ample capacity to place comprehensive programs at competitive prices, we believe there is an opportunity for the industry to provide greater value to clients. Success in our industry is increasingly based on delivering what matters to clients: service; breadth of products; coverage innovation; contract certainty; claims performance; responsiveness; and yes, competitive pricing. Even in this tough market environment, underwriters continue to offer new products and services that meet the growing risk needs of our clients, and this bodes well for our industry to grow and enhance the value we deliver.
On the health care side, we've seen recent news about proposed health insurer consolidation in the U.S. There is continued uncertainty regarding outcomes, especially in light of the recently filed DOJ lawsuits to block 2 possible mergers. Mercer will continue to be a trusted adviser regardless of the outcome of these proposed mergers. We will help our clients navigate all the options to design and implement benefit programs that are high quality and cost-effective for employees and their families.
Now let me turn to our results. MMC produced solid operating performance in the second quarter with underlying revenue growth across all 4 of our operating companies, margin expansion and 14% growth in adjusted earnings per share. MMC's revenue of $3.4 billion was the largest quarter in our history. Consolidated underlying revenue growth was 3% with excellent growth and profitability. Operating income rose 16% or 14% on an adjusted basis. For the 6-month period, underlying revenue growth was 4% with margin expansion in both segments and 8% growth in adjusted earnings per share.
Looking at Risk and Insurance Services. Second quarter revenue increased 6% with both Marsh and Guy Carpenter contributing. Underlying revenue growth was 2%. Adjusted operating income increased double digits with the margin expanding 140 basis points to 26.8%, our highest second quarter margin since 1988.
I'm excited about the addition of top-flight leadership talent into RIS, reporting to Peter Zaffino. There are no finer P&C executives than John Doyle, the President of Marsh; and Peter Hearn, the President and CEO of Guy Carpenter. I am certain that John and Peter will have a positive impact on MMC.
I would like to give a special acknowledgment to Alex Moczarski and thank him for his leadership of Guy Carpenter over the past 5 years. We all look forward to working with Alex in his role as Chairman, MMC International.
The Consulting segment also delivered a strong quarter with revenue increasing 4%. On an underlying basis, revenue grew 5% with both Mercer and Oliver Wyman producing solid underlying revenue growth. Adjusted operating income increased double digits and the adjusted operating margin expanded 230 basis points to 18.7%, the segment's highest second quarter margin in over 30 years.
In summary, we are pleased with our second quarter results. We are a trusted adviser, helping our clients address the issues of the day relating to risk, strategy and people. Demand for our advice and services increases in a world filled with uncertainty. We have a leadership team that has proven its ability to grow revenue, expand margins and improve earnings each year over multiple years. And we have the financial strength and resources to manage through periods of stress and capitalize on opportunities.
Notwithstanding the headlines and the noise in the market, we expect to deliver another year of excellent financial performance in 2016.
For the full year, we continue to expect underlying revenue growth within the 3% to 5% range that we have operated in for the past 6 years, meaningful margin expansion in both segments and strong EPS growth at a level approaching our long-term target of 13%. All this while continuing to invest in our future and return capital to shareholders through dividends and substantial share repurchases.
With that, let me turn it over to Mark to review our second quarter results in more detail.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dan. Good morning, everyone. In the second quarter, MMC delivered strong results, driven by underlying revenue growth in each of our operating companies while continuing to actively manage expenses. Overall revenue was up 5% and underlying reve
componenttext:
Thank you, Dan. Good morning, everyone. In the second quarter, MMC delivered strong results, driven by underlying revenue growth in each of our operating companies while continuing to actively manage expenses. Overall revenue was up 5% and underlying revenue increased 3%. Adjusted operating income increased by double digits, and our overall margin expanded by 190 basis points. GAAP EPS rose 17% to $0.90 and adjusted EPS increased 14% to $0.91.
Looking at risk and insurance services. Second quarter revenue was $1.8 billion with underlying growth of 2%. Adjusted operating income increased 11% to $493 million with the margin expanding 140 basis points to 26.8%.
At Marsh, revenue in the quarter was $1.6 billion, an increase of 6%. The top line was bolstered by quality acquisitions, such as Jelf in the U.K. and continued activity in Marsh & McLennan agency. On an underlying basis, revenue rose 2%. Underlying growth was 4% in the international division. EMEA increased a solid 3% with growth across all region. Asia Pacific was up 2% and Latin America had a strong growth of 11%. In the U.S./Canada division, underlying revenue was flat. We continue to see pressure in Canada and in parts of the U.S., largely driven by commodity-related headwinds. Guy Carpenter's revenue was $285 million, an increase of 3% on both a recorded and underlying basis. Another good performance. Growth was highlighted by strong new business across Asia Pacific, EMEA in Global Specialties. Guy Carpenter has produced positive underlying revenue growth in 28 of the past 30 quarters.
In the Consulting segment, revenue rose 4% to $1.5 billion or 5% on an underlying basis. Adjusted operating income increased 18% to $288 million and the adjusted operating margin expanded 230 basis points to 18.7%.
Mercer's revenue increased 3% to $1.1 billion, reflecting underlying growth of 4%. Solid growth in the quarter reflects the benefits of the diversified portfolio. Investments and talent both rose 6%, health increased 5% and retirement was up 2%.
All major geographic regions contributed, led by growth market. Oliver Wyman continued to perform well. Revenue was $460 million, reflecting solid growth of 5% on both the reported and underlying basis. Growth was well distributed with particular strength in Europe and other international markets.
In the third quarter, we expect to see a decline in underlying revenue from Oliver Wyman. This is driven by comparisons to very strong growth in the financial services practice last year as well as global growth concerns exacerbated by Brexit uncertainty.
As Dan said, we continue to expect that for 2016, we will generate underlying revenue growth in the 3% to 5% range, increased operating margins in both segments and strong growth in earnings per share.
Let's take a -- make a few comments about our global retirement plan. We normally discuss the outlook for retirement plan expense after we have completed the annual year-end measurement process. However, given the declines in the interest rates, we want to share some thoughts that might be helpful to investors. We monitor our retirement programs on an ongoing basis. Previously, we discussed several changes that have reduced the sensitivity of our retirement expense to interest rates. As we have said many times, we view retirement expenses as just 1 component of overall expense, which we actively manage. We have been effectively mitigating retirement plan volatility and limiting the impact to shareholders over the past couple of years. Based on where we stand today, we expect to do so in 2017.
Moving to investment income. We recognized $1 million in the second quarter, a decrease from $3 million a year ago. For 2016, we expect to generate only modest investment income compared with $38 million we reported in 2015.
On our last earnings call, we estimated the impact from foreign exchange would be de minimis for the remainder of 2016. As expected, the effect of foreign exchange on adjusted EPS was negligible in the second quarter, and our outlook for the rest of the year has not changed. There has been recent volatility in the British pound. Weakening of the pound has minimal overall impact to MMC. This is because RIS has a natural hedge created by U.S. dollar placements in London. While the weakening of -- while the impact of a weakening pound to MMC in total was not significant, there would be a benefit to RIS, offset by an adverse impact to consulting.
Our tax rate fluctuates from quarter-to-quarter, reflecting the geographic mix of earnings, tax settlements, completion of open tax years and other items. Our adjusted tax rate in the second quarter was 29.1% compared to 27.4% in the same quarter last year. Through the first half of the year, our adjusted tax rate was 28.8% compared with 28.5% in last year's first half. Based on the current landscape, it is reasonable to assume a tax rate of 29% for the remainder of 2016.
Corporate debt at June 30 was $4.8 billion, which declined from $5 billion at the end of the first quarter due to a reduction in commercial paper outstanding. The term structure of our debt portfolio provides us flexibility with modest near-term repayment obligations. Our net debt maturity is $250 million of senior notes due next April.
In the second quarter, we repurchased 3.5 million shares of our stock for $225 million. Through 6 months, we used $425 million to buy back 7 million shares. The second quarter marks the 17th consecutive quarter we have bought back our stock, and we have reduced shares outstanding 9 quarters in a row. Since announcing our commitment to reduce our annual share count at Investor Day in March 2014, shares outstanding have declined by 30 million or 5%. Our cash position at the end of the second quarter was $974 million with approximately $170 million in the U.S. Uses of cash in the second quarter included $225 million for share repurchases, $165 million for dividends and $47 million for acquisitions. For the first 6 months, uses of cash included $425 million for share repurchases, $326 million for dividends and $168 million for acquisitions.
For the full year 2016, we continue to expect to deploy roughly $2.3 billion of capital through dividends, share repurchases, acquisitions and investments. We also expect to deliver on our annual capital return commitments to reduce our share count and increase our dividends per share by double digits.
And with that, I'm happy to turn it back to Dan.
